pros: People at public outreach are more than just wholesome. They are supportive, understanding and well respected
cons: Some days the job gets tough certainly during rainy days

review_title: Fulfilling work with room for improvement
pros: Meaningful work: Public Outreach Fundraising focuses on important causes, and it feels rewarding to contribute to them. Supportive team: The colleagues and supervisors at Public Outreach Fundraising are friendly and encouraging, creating a positive work environment. Professional development: There are opportunities for growth and learning through training programs and skill-building workshops. Flexible scheduling: The company offers flexible work hours, which is convenient for maintaining a work-life balance.
cons: High turnover: There is a noticeable turnover rate among employees, which can disrupt team dynamics and create a sense of instability. Pressure to meet targets: The fundraising targets can sometimes feel overwhelming, leading to high stress levels among employees. Limited advancement opportunities: While there are training programs, the opportunities for career advancement within the company can be limited.

pros: Great to meet people and make friends, flexible hours, great for students
cons: Micromanagement, long hours, no additional compensation other than hourly pay, a lot of workplace drama

pros: Good pay for the job
cons: Not alot of growth opportunities

pros: - flexible hours - decent pay
cons: - time consuming - no commission

pros: Challenges you to speak with people you might not normally.
cons: Working in the cold and getting rejected time and again but having to continue

review_title: It can work as a temporary job while looking for an 'actual' job
pros: Hourly pay was good - it was about $20 / hour when I worked for the company
cons: They make you fundraise in the most horrible weather conditions outdoors and they do not seem to care about your wellbeing. A lot of times, I could not find any washrooms while fundraising. Most of my co workers, including the manager were guys so I saw them going to the bathroom 'in the middle of nowhere' but that was not possible for a female worker like myself. They told me and other female fundraisers 'Not to use the bathroom' until we finished our 6-hour fundraising shift with absolutely no bathroom break, and that was pretty bad.

job_title: Remote Call Center Agent in Toronto, ON
pros: Flexible Schedule, great team environment, always helpful
cons: Sometimes required to push certain callers for additional funds which leads to uncomfortable conversations especially when they are low-income.

pros: Flexible work Easy tasks Easy hiring process
cons: Unorganized Unprofessional Needs better communication

review_title: I worked for PO for a year; It's a good way door way for sales, but very much not meant for everyone.
pros: - Great work environment - Taking time off is relatively easy - Bonuses - IF YOU ARE VERY EXTROVERTED AND ALREADY RELATIVELY CHARISMATIC, THIS IS A GOOD JOB FOR YOU, IF YOU ARE NOT, THIS IS NOT FOR YOU. - Schedule flexibility - Pay makes talking to some of the most difficult people you'll ever talk to in your life seem worth it.
cons: Before I say: when looking at the good reviews, I want you to pay attention to how long these people have been working at the company, I think I knew maybe a total of about 2 people who were not management nor formerly management who has worked there for over a year. The average person lasts maybe 2 months max at this job. - If you work on phones: You only get paid for the time that you are on your computer, dialling, or writing notes, and any admin hours, anytime you're off the computer you don't get paid meaning if you come in for an 8-hour shift, you're most likely getting paid for 6.5 or less, probably less. - If you work on streets: If you will constantly be racing to beat your goal, if you don't raise money for over a week and a half, you'll be put on an action plan and most likely given a harder assignment, and then you'll be let go. - The management are all dating each other, married, engaged, dating, it hasn't caused much of an issue when I was there, but it's a disaster waiting to happen. - You WILL be asked to pressure people to donate (even when they are financially not well at times) way beyond your comfort level, and either you find a better strategy to raise money, you suck it up or find another job. - If you are a good fundraiser they will talk to you about a promotion, get you to write briefings, train other fundraisers, and then just never promote you so essentially get you to do the work without the pay.

review_title: Dont work here if you want a secure job.
pros: Pick your own schedule Decent pay Decent work environment
cons: Completely performance-based A lot of "charities" they work with are sketchy They fire people without any notice or warning

review_title: Door to Door Fundraiser Job Review
job_title: Door to Door Fundraiser in Toronto, ON
pros: For a student, it is a good way of making decent money. Good Part-time job You drastically increase your persuasion skills and confidence in relaying a message.
cons: Grueling walking in the cold in Winter Wouldn't say it is something permanent Susceptible to a lot of rejection

pros: It was a nice environment and good incentives
cons: The hours were not ideal for my time zone

pros: Get to work outside, compensation, rewards
cons: Staffed by 18-25 year olds and it shows

pros: The employers and employees at Ottawa and Toronto are fantastic. I came here not knowing what to expect, and was blown away with how supportive, patient, and flexible Public Outreach is. They are so flexible in terms of schedules for students. You also get to learn how to fundraise, how to get out of your comfort zone (Mall, outside, door-to-door, telephone) when interacting with potential donors, and most importantly how to improve yourself constantly. Many activities and incentives are there to help you succeed. You need to be passionate about NGOs and be eager to learn to succeed in this job. You also have to meet a specific quota of donations per day/ at the end of the week, so slacking off isn't an option.
cons: It's a demanding job that needs focus, patience, and resilience. It can be tough to be rejected by people and to stay active outside or by phone for long amounts of time (especially in winter). The staff, positivity, and knowing that you signed up donors makes up for it though (and breaks).

pros:
Flexible schedule/time off for exams, holidays, summer, etc
Great for university students
Team work, great training 
Intense knowledge regarding NGO’s
Great connections
cons:
Questions if company is ethical 
Pressure on meeting “sales” targets for monthly donor sign ups
Can get fired if not meeting targets
Being shown that passive aggressive/pushy behaviour is acceptable when approaching potential donors (strangers)
Work in outside conditions all year round, however, there are in door positions available as well

pros: I can’t think of any pros
cons:
Where to begin.. we were forced to work during the pandemic when no one wore masks. When Toronto malls shut down we were forced to commute to malls outside the city. This was when everything was closed, we had a both set up and no break room. The food courts were all closed and there was no seating in the malls. It was winter so I couldn’t eat outside and you weren’t allowed to eat in the malls. So for my hour lunch break I had to just wonder around and couldn’t eat anywhere. I remember one day I broke down when a security guard at the mall asked me not yo eat inside because I was starving and exhausted from standing all day, and my commute had been over 1:30. 

I was pressured into going on an over night tour and the manager who drove me didn’t wear a mask in the car, then forced me to follow and promote her side make up business. The hotel we stayed in was under construction and I felt very unsafe. 

When we finally moved into the office on the phones, no one was wearing a mask and we were crammed into a small very poorly ventilated room. I said I wouldn’t continue to work there unless I could work from home.

Your job is always threaten because we have to raise a certain amount in monthly donations a week to keep your job. If you didn’t meet the target you were fired. The managers were so desperate to meet their targets they would tell us to straight up lie to people to get monthly donations. If anyone gave a one time donation you were told it wasn’t good enough and you should’ve been able to convince that person to give monthly. I once got a $200 one time donation from a lovely woman and was told it was embarrassing that I couldn’t convince her to give monthly. A lot of throng we were told to say conflicted with the actual charity’s information on where money actually goes and I saw many people tell blatant lies to people about how much they could claim on taxes.

pros: Great culture. You will work with people with good values. Flexible schedule. Making an impact on the world
cons: It's not the job for everybody. Can be challenging at times.

review_title: It's okay, but you wouldn't want to be there for long.
pros:
Everyone's extremely nice and it's a very casual and relaxed work environment. Everyone tries their best to help you, and while I was let go after only a few weeks, it wasn't a negative experience whatsoever. I understand they have numbers to reach. Like any sales job, there's gonna be a high turnover rate and many people aren't going to be great at it.

You can choose your own schedule and hours each week, which is nice. Very flexible.
cons:
I think the biggest issue is when you come in thinking that you are flat-out going to be doing something morally praiseworthy here. Sure, you're learning about NGOs and you're helping raise money for those NGOs to help important causes, but often times, you're doing it by emotionally manipulating and pressuring people into donating, which doesn't feel great, even if it is for a greater cause. Sometimes you'll get people on the phone who just got out of the hospital, just had kids, or had some other big, expensive event happen to them and you're supposed act like you totally understand their situation and empathize with them, but if they just stopped drinking a coffee every few days they could donate 20+ dollars a month to something that has little to nothing to do with them. It's all just means to an end to helping people, and it's up to you to justify whether you're okay with those means. 

Getting hired is easy, but it doesn't mean you have a job here. You need to go through training, and if they decide you're not doing great, they'll let you go right there. Then you're on a trial period getting paid 15/hr, but if you don't get your numbers up consistently after 1 or 2 weeks, they'll let you go. If you last there for 6 months or so, you'll get benefits, but you'd have to be pretty exceptional to last that long. Even if you make it past all this, they'll still let you go if you stop producing numbers, and sometimes it's just down to luck. You're calling random people all day and you don't know if they'll donate. Most don't. In the end, it's just a glorified sales job. If you're not good at sales, set your sights on something else. 

Finally, they continue to emphasize that it isn't cold-calling, but you're calling people from the numbers they gave when they signed a petition on the street. If you've ever signed a petition, did you think you were consenting to being called with fundraising requests for a few months straight? Probably not. This leads to a lot of annoyed people who will straight out ignore you or hang-up on you, and understandably so.

pros: above minimum wage, sometimes your travel is covered
cons:
They don't care about covid or following public health guidelines 
- I went on a "travel trip" to Barrie (because Torontos malls were shutdown) and a manager gave us a ride and the manager and the other 2 employees all did not wear masks for the whole hour drive. 
- Managers will often high five and pat employees on the back without permission
- There is no covid health check 
- If you are sick you have to make up the time off that week and don't have to get a test before returning to work
Lack of communication 
-Schedules are often wrong and people get different ones
- where you go for your shift and who your supervisor is often not communicated and you get conflicting information
The make you be extremely pushy to people to get them to donate
- They make targets and put a lot of pressure on you to meet target and get monthly donations
- They basically tell you to keep pushing until the person either walks away, yells at you or donates. 
- They tell you to tell people misleading things to get people to sign up 
- I have heard a few employees saying things that are false to get donations.

pros: You will meet some great people as coworkers - likeminded individuals who are passionate. It's also a great place to build your patience because of all the things you go through.
cons: Everything else, literally. Read below

review_title: The days can be fun, but the work is challenging and can leave you frustrated
pros:
Fun Co-workers who are willing to help  
Fun socials and morning briefings 
People out on the street can make the day worthwhile if they stop and listen to what you have to say 
Getting someone to sign up as a monthly donor always feels amazing.
Finding out neat things about the people you meet on the street is always interesting - I met a conspiracy theorist once!
cons:
People can yell at you on the street.
You work in any type of weather - really hot, or really cold.
It can feel awkward to be the new "recruit" just coming into what seems like an established group of friends. 
People just ignore your existence on the streets as well.
You're expected to get many donors, but it's hard to get them.  
High, high turnover - new recruits come every two weeks. 
Also - you're not hired at first. You're a new "recruit" for five days, in which you have to get five donors. (one is also paid minimum wage during this time) If you "PAC" five times, then you're  hired. This puts a lot of pressure on the new recruits.

pros: salary, flexibility, team buildings, -
cons: organisation, structure, communication, management, -

pros: Great incentives for employees. Support staff is incredible and always there to help. Your making a difference in your work and you learn so much about different charities and current events
cons: None that I can think of.

review_title: great student job, fair environment, emotionally exhausting
pros: NOT ON COMMISSION!! yay! recognized for your good work, raises recieved fairly often, excellent wage, easy to advance in company, lots of hours given, flexible schedule, fairly friendly environment, opportunites to travel within Canada and US, energetic and understanding environment. Personal style of canvassing fairly respected. your health is respected and if you need a break or a water you wont be penalised or guilted for it.
cons: a little clique-y, more experienced workers less welcoming, insane amount of pressure despite steady wage to get alot of signups. high office gossip level. morning briefings you will be expected to dance around and make a complete fool of yourself (very difficult for introverts) but if you are an introvert-ish person and you can make it work you will not be penalised.

review_title: Not For Everyone But Worth a Try
job_title: Door to Door Fundraiser in Ottawa, ON
pros:
I've worked for Public Outreach's door-to-door team and I had a good experience. 
Pros include:
-Great starting wage (16$/hr once you pass your evaluation)
-Fun team environment with a lot of great people, great after-work social life 
-The feeling that your work is supporting a good cause and making a difference
-Learning lots about world issues
-Constantly being challenge and learning new personal and professional skills (way more engaging for your mind than boring retail) 
-Talking to awesome people at the door
-Working outside on nice days and being active
cons:
Cons include:
-Some pressure to meet fundraising goals, feeling of disappointment if you don't meet your goals, risk of termination if you continually do not reach your goals. 
-Involves a lot of travel time to get to the neighbourhoods to go canvassing
-Working outside in sucky weather
-Constantly being rejected and occasionally spoken down to by people at the door

Conclusion: If you want a job that will challenge you and you have a thick skin (or are interested in learning how to grow one), this could be the job for you. You will meet awesome people and learn tonnes, you will feel great that your work raises money for important causes. If you cannot at all handle people treating you passively or rudely, this may not be for you.

job_title: Senior Fundraising Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Awesome environment to grow in sales experience. Collectively pushing to improve individual donation numbers. Management communication is clear.
cons:
-Disorganization of objectives
-Mismanagement at the Senior level leading to misinformation to fundraisers

pros:
Incredible team, and excellent training and mentoring. They genuinely want you to succeed. It's a lot of fun and all the people there truly care about the work they do. I have massive respect and love for all of the staff there and I am grateful that I was able to meet them while I worked. 
The job itself really helps you build a thick skin and a soft heart, develop communication skills, and attitude and mindset truly depends on your success! It truly pushes you out of your comfort zone but the skills you get to learn can really take you anywhere when moving on to something else. It's not commissioned based as well which is AWESOME, no need to feel disgusting for getting bonuses on getting people involved in a charity since the pay is a flat rate!!
Plus you get to work outside in the sun, yay!
cons:
Attitude and mindset is a double edged sword that can work for you incredibly, in which means that if you are negative you will not succeed. If you're not prepared for the weather as well can be a problem but again it's all on you (they actually give $50 towards winter gear and have feet/hand warmers (another pro!) but I mean.. you know better be extra prepared when you work outside). 
It is truly a team environment and personal effort, so if you can't ask for help and give your very best, don't apply. 
You work outside in the winter!

review_title: Great soft skills training but don't stay long if you are analytical
pros: If you could sign people up to donate, then you kept your job. Simple as that, very few politics around who got credit for the work as it was difficult to take credit for someone else's efforts. Great learning curve in self-management and sales. They were very data-oriented. I also learned a lot about leadership just because the vibe of the team leaders and team members tended to have a lot of impact on team results.  In cubicle jobs, it can be so easy to forget that tone of voice, positive communication, body language, energy-level are so key to team and individual success. If I hadn't learned those lessons, I would have been much less prepared to navigate the deceptive world of office-based careers . It was also great working outdoors.
cons: Analytical and critical thinking abilities were irrelevant to the point of being unwelcome. The company offered very few ways to advance internally other than the traditional sales campaign leader route. A lot of quick thinkers and intelligent people worked there, yet I saw some really smart, sensitive people who weren't the most consistent fundraisers be regularly frustrated by the limited internal opportunities available for growth.   Fantastic soft skills experience, yet bordered on intellectual and creative gaslighting.  It was only a good place to work to hone a very narrow range of skills. Don't get stuck.

pros: Good Environment, meet good people
cons: Fired if does not achieve goals within less than 2 weeks in a row

pros:

cons:

job_title: Door to Door Fundraiser in Toronto, ON
pros: great pay and get to work with great charities
cons: very demanding job both physical and emotional

pros: It's an easy summer job. If you put in the hours and are prepared for a lot of walking, it's very easy to get promoted and move up in the company.
cons: Be prepared to be publicly humiliated and bullied through group chats ran by the managerial staff, or while on the job in front of your coworkers.  If you do not reach your quota for the day group leads will forgo all professionalism and blatantly humiliate you or your coworkers in the group chat. Forget about working as a team, you are all competing against each other for numbers. It stops being about raising money for a good cause and is just about the numbers. The charitable aspect of the company is a facade, in reality it's like any other corporate job that care more about the money than the very people who work for them. For a company that raises money for organizations such as CAMH, it seems hypocritical that the people who are suppose to help train and guide you through the company, have instead created a toxic work place that is detrimental to you and your coworkers mental health.  The senior staff at Public Outreach Toronto have responsibility to reassess their management style in order to reflect that of empathy, encouragement and togetherness.

pros: You support a good cause, they gave me two choices for charities I could canvas for. You also meet a lot of interesting people on the street and overall most people are friendly. If you like speaking to people this job will be a good match for you.  There is a high turnover rate so people were able to be promoted to team leads within less than three months.
cons: The work atmosphere is a bit fake.  Everyone acts like they are your friend right away which was uncomfortable when considering each week there is a new group of people going through training so they are constantly meeting people. The quotas also affected the ability to actually focus on the charity and the cause itself. It felt like everything was about how well you preform not how passionate everyone should be about helping a charity raise money.  I did not live downtown so the job impacted my work life balance negatively. By the time I would reach home in the evening which didn't leave much time for doing other things.

review_title: Best Summer job I've ever had
pros:
- you learn something new every day
- lots of fun team nights and weekly games/activities to keep work fun
- The most passionate/inspiring people stick around to work here long term 
- You get to represent respectable charities like Doctors Without Borders and Amnesty International
- super high energy morning briefings that feel more like summer camp than work
- not a commission based job so a lot of stress is lifted
 - lots of room to grow in the company
 - travel trips with coworkers (friends!) 
- being paid to actually make a difference is literally the best feeling !!
cons:
- not everyone has the communication skills needed for this job so it sucks to see fun people get let go after not being able to fundraise well. 
- I see a TON of negative reviews below and I honestly think it's because the company gives a LOT of people a shot...but I've canvassed with many who are simply in it for a paycheck and don't care about the charity at all. Those are the people who don't pass their training and get bitter and VOCAL over being fired even though zero donations have been raised.

review_title: SCAM. You are NOT supporting CHARITIES you are pushing for sales to benefit Public Outreach
pros: temporarily fun work environment. develop interpersonal skills, active, at times motivational, educated on international poverty issues.
cons: Unprofessional management, bullying between juvenile coworkers -breaches in confidentiality, sales based: pushed to sell regardless of the persons status ( why would I want to guilt a young single mother into sponsoring a child in a developing country when she can hardly afford to make her own ends meet? You're in  trouble if you don't) False job description: There is pressure on you at all times to sell regardless of what's going on. Unsafe work environment: manager expected us to continue canvassing on the street 250 m's away from a stabbing. There were police officers and EMS everyehere and we were expected to sell sponsorships and lectured when we did not. That would classify as an Occupational Health and Safety Hazard. How much money can possibly go to the charities when they're wasting time canvassing in low income neighbourhoods, and have several staff that rarely get children sponsored. Is 6 staff getting paid $90/day each going to benefit the charity when they only get 3 children sponsored.  This place is a scam and isn't even registered with the Better Business Bureau.

review_title: Once you pass the first week, you're in the clear!
pros:
Great work environment and amazing people working as a team. Very progressive, fun people. You will become very close with the people around you
Tons of leadership and travel opportunities if you want them.
Sometimes you get to work with really awesome non-profits.
Full benefits.
Very supportive leadership that are willing to help you if you are willing to work hard.
Good incentives.
Working outdoors.
Easy to get an interview. Equal opportunity for everyone. You don't need experience or post-secondary.
cons:
The job can be stressful at times. Fundraisers have targets to hit, and new employees often aren't prepared for that. 
The evaluation (hiring) process is difficult and many trainees don't make it past their first week. This process is years old and should be fixed! I've seen many *good* people let go because they didn't pick up on it right away.

pros: Working at Public Outreach has been a great experience for me.  It challenges you to grow and develop skills that are highly valuable for future workplaces.  I've learned a lot about talking with people confidently, sharing my passions, and developing the skills of people the work alongside me.  Public Outreach is an energetic working environment that gives you a platform on which to be a part of much needed change both locally and globally.
cons: Because Public Outreach focuses on raising funds for charities, its important that we keep our response high.  This means that there is pressure on canvassers to turn their conversations into charitable contributions.  For me, this is fun and rewarding, however it's understandable that this is not a job that suits everyone's personalities.

pros:
- Fun interview, which was more of an info session than an interview
- Decent pay if you can pass training
- Can get benefits after 6 months
- I have heard some teams are good
cons:
- Bad coaching once I met my team
- Was paired with another trainee on the first day once we got the the location for fundraising, rather than being paid with an experienced fundraiser to learn
- Worked alone for a couple hours on the first day
- Had to ask to be trained, then got attitude from the coach
- Emailed the team managers after the first day to express how bad it was and how that is not training should be handled and to quit the job because I don't want to work for a company like that, did not even get a reply to the email
- Bad for the self-esteem, as everyone just walks by because you are annoying them on the streets
- Not sure how any sponsorship money supports the kids when fundraisers are paid and bring in less in one shift than they are being paid for that shift.

review_title: Very bad coordination and workplace organization - Try not to work here
pros:
- $14 per hour salary
- Good if you are a student as its a very flexible schedule
- They support you when they can
- Positive attitude
cons:
- Very little to no organization
- Fundraising goal to meet otherwise you get fired
- Will fire you without any reason, if you get sweaty once you get fired (Hard not to sweat in the summer when you are working OUTDOORS)
- There is a reason they are always looking for employees since so many people leave or get fired.
- Can lead to depression or sad thoughts as you work with mental health fundraising and have to talk about suicide and depression. You might hear the stories of people's relatives committing suicide.
- You are shamed if you don't meet their 3.3 PAC per hour client goal. Have to talk about it and say why you couldn't meet it.

pros:
Challenging job that leaves you feeling great at the end of the day
Amazing people to work with and work for
Really encouraging team environment
Fantastic Growth Opportunities - I'm now managing a national recruitment department at 27 years old, I would not have this chance anywhere else
Really competitive pay and lots of opportunities for raises based on performance/tenure
Lots of emphasis on work-life balance, very understanding regrading time off, etc...
cons:
Can be a little bit taxing dealing with rude people who don't care about charity
Working in the cold gets a bit dreary after a while
Pay is good, but it would be tough to raise a family on it

pros: Everyday you wake up knowing you are going on the street trying to support these children around the world.
cons:
Winters are very very cold
They only tell you not to work outdoors if it reaches -30° but if it’s -28° they will keep you working. 
Personally I feel like there are better ways to fundraise than on the street. 
It’s a hard job and very mentally draining to constantly have high energy, and when I say you have to have high energy I mean you HAVE to have high energy all the time even when people tell you right to your face that they hate the charity you are fundraising for or that they hate women. It is a very demanding job and days feel like they drag on. 
At the end of the day so many people refuse to talk to you that it feels like your making little to no impact on these children of family suffering

review_title: Well intentioned, but a difficult model to be successful with.
pros: great culture and supportive colleagues all working toward a very important set of goals with real impact on the world. I also felt that management wanted the staff to hit targets and were willing to give advice and coaching to attempt to raise numbers, although those numbers had very little flexibility in them.
cons: A difficult sales model with a fair bit of emotional strain and production targets that I felt were very tight. also some inter office friction and politics at the location I worked at.

pros: The staff and management were fun, friendly, and motivated to do a great job. A really great team spirit. I learned so much about door to door sales/fundraising its not even funny. Working outside was excellent. There was a feeling that your work was meaningful and that you were creating a positive impact.
cons: If you had a bad day (no 'PAC') then there was little reason to celebrate. Individual performance metrics massively impacted my self esteem, and it was easy to spiral into a slump. It takes a very specific combination of personality traits to succeed in this job out of the gate; most people burn out and others just get bored. I felt that the high pressure to PAC and the weekly performance reviews do not allow employees to grow and really succeed at the challenging work.

pros:
Decent Atmosphere

Supporting Good Causes?

Pay & hours are alright for students.
cons:
It is all a lie. They stress "we don't work on commission" which technically is true. HOWEVER. If you don't PAC they can you, no if ands or buts. There is zero job security. Zerp investment into employees. You are a number - don't let them fool you. 

If this wasn't bad enough, they are the most disorganized employer I have ever dealt with...and I have dealt with the government. Management is impossible to get a hold of, and everything...from pay management to responsibility, is deflected to other people in the company.

If employees actually spoke out about the way PO treats their employees, I am absolutely confident PO would be ruined, and this is coming from a current employee himself.

review_title: Not too bad, but would be so much better with proper management
pros:
Super flexible schedule
Pay above minimum wage
Decent people
cons:
Management does literally nothing except create schedules, and sends you to the same turf over and over again, then is surprised when you don't do well
In the last few months, management has gone downhill fast, offers absolutely no coaching, switch training or incentive to do well
There is a lack of guidance and assistance from management if you aren't meeting goal

pros: Great pay especially on 5 hour shifts. Fundraising hours are generally accommodating and you get to experience many parts of Toronto you would not otherwise. You get to meet awesome people.
cons: Competitive environment as a canvasser against other charities. Donor fatigue grows noticeably as the years progress. It can be emotionally taxing having to face rejections all day and rude people.

pros: coworkers are very supportive and willing to give tips on how to fundraise, listen to concerns and help bridge any gaps in pitching, helping to talk to strangers during training.
cons: it's a numbers game. sometimes people are not willing to donate and you start wondering what happens to your job the next week. They're a for-profit being hired to do not-for-profit work, so you fundraise for a cause but worry constantly about making the individual bottom line so you don't get into trouble

review_title: A great way to get started in non-profit work
pros:
This is a workplace where innovation and hard work are always rewarded. 

People from all types of backgrounds are accepted, and can contribute to causes that have a real impact. If you're not sure how to get started with non-profits, or are just looking for a meaningful career then this is a great place to  try. 

There are tonnes of options for advancement, the staff teams are friendly and supportive, and the job is alot of fun if you have the right attitude about meeting new people.
cons: It is a performance based job, laziness is not rewarded because it costs charities money.

pros:
I worked as a telefundraiser. One of my key takeaways from this job was the diversity of the staff. It was incredible. It doesn't matter what your race, gender, educational background education, or age is because you almost certainly will succeed in meshing with the team there - provided you are openminded and respectful of others. Hands on training to build your sales techniques is a fantastic plus for anyone with little sales experience.
The hours are extremely flexible and accommodating for those with second jobs or enrolled in school.
cons: It's a marketing company so if you miss your targets you will be asked to leave.

job_title: Senior Fundraising Manager in Ottawa, ON
pros:
Public Outreach offers an incredibly supportive environment, assuming you're a dedicated, professional employee. The work we undertake for our clients is very real and our international and domestic clients/charities depend heavily on our fundraising dollars. Fundraising, at it's core, is very simple, but not easy. We have created an environment that is not commission-based as we do not want to pressure potential donors nor employees to misrepresent our charitable clients. 

This is also a workplace where you can develop professionally and achieve new heights in your career aspirations. As a social enterprise, our priority is to ensure all staff feel valued and made aware of the opportunities that exist at Public Outreach (and beyond). This is NOT an easy job, but it is one that is incredibly fulfilling and rewarding. 

You get to contribute to the greater good as illustrated by our incredible relationships with our charitable partners. Without the donations we raise, much of our partners' work in the field would be impossible to undertake. We may seem like a relaxed, casual workspace - and we are - but the impact we have is second-to-none. 

Starting wage is $16 per hour with ample opportunity to increase this hourly wage. Once you become part of our management team, compensation becomes salaried and is very lucrative, despite the stereotypes about fundraising.
cons: Due to the nature of this work - performance-based - it can be difficult to find suitable candidates who excel in such an environment. This accounts for a significant number of otherwise qualified candidates who simply cannot perform in the fundraising world. This is exactly the reason why we have created a strong support network - if you show up prepared to work, you will find an incredibly welcoming network of passionate fundraisers. Similarly, as we attract applicants from all walks of life, it is easy for some to assume that we are not a professional workspace and this can lead to conduct issues. We welcome students, part-time (etc.) candidates, but as alluded to above, this is NOT JUST a place to have fun. Treat this as you would any other employment opportunity and you will succeed.

pros: I had some of the best coworkers, most effective, caring on-the-job training in this company as a neighborhood canvasser, couldn't have asked for better colleagues!
cons: A bit informal, as workplaces go. The work itself is fairly stressful, as there are quotas to fulfill (though they are not particularly difficult and the staff, again, are very understanding). The job is based a little on skill and a lot on luck, so it can be tricky to stay motivated.

review_title: If you can survive the guilt, and targets
pros: Casual work environment, good if you can get along with the people there, but they are all more or less welcoming. Younger demographic, mostly liberal arts students who don't have many other choices for a decent jobs. Its flipping burgers or this, but only if you can survive and sell.
cons:
You are essentially selling child sponsorships.
Half the things you are taught about the charities aren't necessarily true, and you will have to live with the guilt of guilt tripping honest people into surrendering their credit cards to sponsor a child.

pros:
Fun working atmosphere - not only did I get to work with people who have become lifelong friends but the culture is amazing. Fun and ridiculous over the top theme weeks connected to our fundraising targets, to events at Pride, and lemonade stands! 

Networking with Non-Profits - they would regularly post job opporutnities both internally and with the charities

Personal development.  When I started this job I was a bit "too cool for school" but by connecting with people I may have normally never been friends with outside of working at Public Outreach not only did I expand my social network but expanded my ability to connect to different types of people, improved my communication skills, learned more about myself and the world and social issues.

Leadership Opportunities!

Supportive and understanding leadership and management! They really care about your success. I found some of my colleagues were resistant to transparency with management and those people are the ones who wouldn't succeed.

Flexible schedules and and understanding leadership team.  It was great being able to have a flexible schedule.  My manager was very understanding whenever I had personal issues come up or had auditions for roles that came up! It was great to tailor my schedule to what was going on in my lfie and have support from my leaders.

Health Benefits - I chipped my tooth thank god I had dental hahaha

As a member of the LGBT community I felt at home every single day and that I could be myself.  Its a place that celebrates individuality and diversity 

Coming in to work every day in what can sometimes be a challenging job was always a joy! The people you meet, both donors and staff and management are some of the best people you will ever meet and you will have a ton of fun while you do it.
cons:
Sometimes having negative interactions with people on the street could be demotivating, but the support of my team and leaders was great.

If you don't have a team player or positive attitude its probably not the right job for you.  I found people who had attitudes or a sense of entitlement clashed with other team members and leadership.

It is a performance based job (they are very transparent about that and what the goals are, they tell you this extensively in the interview, training and post training process) which for people not up to the challenge of hitting targets could be difficult.  I found some people would come in and be really surprised that they were expected to perform or wanted like lots of time to "figure it out". 

If you dont have an open growth mindset and are unwilling to accept constructive feedback its also probably not the right environment

review_title: Best Job on the Planet - If You Earn It!
pros:
-It's not hard to be a fundraiser. You just need to have a great personality and attitude and be passionate about the cause you're representing
-What you put into the job, you get back - if you're willing to work really hard and grow as a person/fundraiser the company rewards you with travel, career growth, benefits, and skills for life. Similarly, if you are negative and not willing to put in the work, the job is clearly not a good fit and you will not have a positive experience. A real choose your own adventure type job!
-Learning about and working for some of the world's best and most transparent charities
-Opportunity to work with charities directly (internships, permanent jobs, etc.)
-Working with some of the most dynamic, energetic people you will ever meet
-The entire job is standing outside/inside talking to people about things you're passionate about. That's it. The job is as easy or as hard as YOU decide it is.
-Non-commission, guaranteed hourly wage with opportunity for raises and leadership
-More of a lifestyle than a typical clock in/clock out kind of job.
cons:
-Not everyone will stop, so you have to be very self-aware about your perspective and innovate new ways to handle rejection.
-Performance based jobs can always be a little stressful, so you have to challenge yourself to get good at handling rejection and meeting targets
-As is the nature of the job, a lot of things can change at the drop of a hat (learning a new charity/working on a new medium, etc.) so you have to make the most of every day and consistently bring your best self
-If you are simply looking for a paycheck, this job is not for you. It requires a lot of passion, energy, and leadership skills.

pros: PO represents a number of awesome charities. Fundraisers work door-to-door, street or mall depending on the campaign. Coworkers are typically young, energetic, enthusiastic, idealistic and fun. It's good ground floor training for any sort of sales and if you stick at it, you will become very comfortable talking to all sorts of people. And that's a good thing.
cons: It's very challenging to meet weekly "sales" quotas. Random one-time donations are not the point, what PO and their clients want are ongoing monthly donations and you have to sign up a certain amount per week.

review_title: Evaluation = No Job Security, Look for another job
pros:
- Relaxed environment
- You get to have great conversations with people
- Representing amazing organizations
cons:
- Sales driven. A profit driven organization that represents non-profits.
- You're basically on commission even though they tell you you're not
- Base salary during your evaluation
- People don't usually last through evaluation ie. they're fired after 5 days if the team does not think you are worthy enough
- You must have 5 sponsors in 5 days during the evaluation

review_title: Great team culture and a real impact
job_title: Senior Fundraising Manager in Ottawa, ON
pros: Working with public outreach is one of the most direct ways to make an impact on the world around you. Everyone wants to be an 'activist' but not many people are very active.... this is a very supportive and effective environment to get started in. In my time here I've helped raise literally millions of dollars of funding for some causes that I care the most about.
cons: Working outdoors and facing rejection are definitely hurdles to get over. Very achievable with the support of your team though.

pros:
- You get to work with really nice, helpful people who want to see you succeed
- Good starting pay
- No one holds you back insofar as advancement through the company goes, as long as you have the willingness and the skills, seniority is not a huge factor
cons:
- Pretty large employee turnover rate
- Sometimes it can be difficult to hit goals and it makes the job more stressful and difficult to do
- Sometimes outside factors that are out of your control are not considered in whether or not you're successful

pros: Public Outreach offers a flexible schedule and supportive supervisors that help you meet your fundraising targets.
cons: You get fired if you cannot meet fundraising targets. Losing your job puts a lot of pressure on you. Also, the work is done primarily outdoors (unless it is over the phone) so you are exposed to adverse weather conditions and potentially dangerous people.

pros:
-Very flexible work hours
-Great people to work with
-You get lots of feedback and support for your performance
-No experience or specific degree needed
-You're contributing to a good cause
cons:
-Low pay
-It's hard work and is definitely not for everyone.
-You spend the whole day outside even in bad weather
-Some people can be extremely rude so you need to have thick skin
-Extremely difficult to make it through the evaluation process

review_title: If you can sell, you'll do well.
pros:
-Work with nice people.
-Get to be outside and move around.
-Decent pay.
cons:
-Work outside (no matter the weather).
- Couldn't sell to 6 people so I got fired the first week.
- Training didn't focus on what it should have, I was trying to convince people to donate to charity without knowing a lot about the charity.
-Some people on the street get mad and start yelling/swearing at you.

pros: If you really like talking to people, if you really enjoy working with outgoing dynamic charity fundraisers, public outreach is the best please. Also, you won't have to get up early for work everyday. Can improve your communication to the next level.
cons: Not much technical skills required. Might have to talk to more than 70 people and knock door to door. Long working hours from 12:30 pm to 9pm.

review_title: It's recovering from a period of sub-par upper management
pros:
-Culture, learning, opportunity for growth and personal development.
-Ability to hone in on invaluable soft skills - interpersonal skills, communication skills, problem solving.
cons:
-You don't get the chance to learn any "harder skills" valued in other workplaces.
-The job becomes repetitive very easily.

pros: The best work culture to exist in. The structure of the company attracts the right type of people - energetic, positive, and caring. Not everyone is outgoing, but that does not mean that you cannot succeed in this fundraising position.
cons: Face to Face fundraising is not for everyone, and if you do not meet objectives you will not keep your job. That being said, your managers do everything they can do ensure you do your best.

pros: The management staff is incredibly supportive when you encounter the demands of the job. This is absolutely a demanding position, however the team around you is what makes the difference.  No commission, skilled-based fundraising.
cons: You're dealing with members of the public and they don't always agree with you. You're also working outside, which can be demanding.

pros: Great job for students looking for Part Time work. Fun co workers, get to grow and gain interpersonal skills. Good if you’re competitive and extroverted, especially goal driven since you have to meet target every day.
cons: Poor management, childish and unprofessional managers. Basically runs like a summer camp. Extremely competitive, pure sales job, barely feels like you’re doing anything for the charity itself. No job security, can get fired at any time if not meeting targets.

review_title: Public Outreach has a collegial culture, flexible working hours, good staff development processes. Like a university!
pros: Astonishingly supportive company with a great culture of allowing innovation by employees. Many leadership opportunities. Benefits plan after relatively short wait. Travel opportunities. Bursaries.
cons: Public Outreach does not pay high salaries, and their termination process needs fixing. Can be hard for some to maintain the required level of performance.

review_title: Fantastic no strings attached summer job. Terrible place for a career.
pros: Decent pay, they hire people from many backgrounds, benefits and flexibility. If you there for a summer job and need some cash, this job is perfect but if you have come to PO for a career, enter at your own risk.
cons: The company mission statement is Honest, Effective and Respectful and sadly that is not the case. The company is poorly run and morally bankrupt. Complete lack of transparency in management decisions, little follow through on promises, spying, manipulations, bullying and discrimination by middle management on a frequent basis.

review_title: Great Entry into the non-profit industry
pros: Great vision, fun atmosphere and the people are really enjoyable to work with. This job will strengthen your communication and resilience.
cons: Lack of communication between departments, can be stressful if you aren't properly supported by your manager or have trouble talking to 100's of people a week.

review_title: Great Place to Work if you Love Charity!
pros:
-room to grow with the company (I was moved into a new role within 3 months of employment)
-great culture (very friendly and supportive staff in all departments and offices)
-representing influential charities and learning more about them 
-meeting new people while fundraising
-working outside, especially in the summer
-fun activities for staff (sports, movies, etc)
cons: -working in the heat sometimes

job_title: Senior Fundraising Manager in Vancouver, BC
pros: Flexible schedule, amazing culture (all of my best friends have come from this job!), impactful work and rewarding to be a part of the campaigns, limitless in term of where you can go within the company (lots of lesdership opportunities), tons of travel opportunitys and very collaborative
cons: Results based jobs can sometimes be stressful, also can be odd hours depending on what type of fundraising you do

pros: The recruitment department is a great place to work. We look after each other and make sure we are all doing the best job we can, when it comes to goals, targets, leadership.
cons: The other departments don't seem to understand the importance of recruitment when it is essential part of this company.

review_title: Unethical, Disorganized, Lack of Transparency, Cult-like
pros: Flexible schedule. You get a lot of exercise walking around neighbourhoods and knocking on doors. You meet some interesting people. That's literally it.
cons:
Where do I even begin? Everything about this company is shady as hell. I will proceed in list form.

1) They advertise their positions at well above minimum wage, but the "training" wage is only minimum wage. If you don't sign up 3 people in the first 3 days, you get fired. So most employees never see the advertised wage.

2) It is misleadingly advertised as work in the non-profit sector. Rest assured, this is a FOR-profit organization whose goal is to take a cut from non-profit organizations. The starting position is sales-- high-pressure sales. If you don't meet their targets, you're gone.

3) Continuing on from the previous point, I was encouraged to pressure low-income individuals into donating because they were more likely to give in than wealthy people. Absolutely immoral. I do not know if this occurs in other branches of PO, but I would not be surprised. 

5) Some managers are well-intentioned, but almost all lack the necessary experience and training required to manage effectively. There is zero protection for employees who experience verbal or sexual harrassment from prospective donors, fellow employees, and even management themselves! It is obvious that whoever is responsible for promoting and hiring has no idea what they are doing. Upper management obviously doesn't care either. Extremely toxic work environment.

6) Building on the previous point, those that stay in the company have a cult-ish attitude. The training session was extremely culty. I question the judgement and morality of anyone who stays there longer than a few months (barring absolute necessity).

7) The work itself can be physically demanding and at times unsafe. You are working outside in all weather conditions. The weather part is listed in the job description, but they leave out the part where you can face verbal and sometimes even physical assault at this job (especially if you're working on the streets).

To summarize, if you see this job advertised on any job board... Run! And please, be nice to the folks who are stuck working there. They are having a rough time.

pros: As a supervisor and a fundraiser at Public Outreach, I'm encouraged to share my ideas and I can participate with my own vision, working alongside wonderful people, each person brings something to the table and I love the fact that i get to grow and learn in such an open and equal environment
cons: working in fundraising and all, it is a disorganized environment sometimes

review_title: Helps you grow as a person
pros:
- Very flexible in terms of hours and shifts, perfect for students
- Super understanding, they are like a family and they are concerned about you
- You develop interpersonal skills, teambuilding skills, communication skills and really grow as a person 
- Every day is a different day, so it is refreshing
cons: There aren't any downsides that I have experienced throughout my experience here

review_title: You can earn a lot of money as a fundraiser if you excel at manipulation.
pros:
-pays well
-great work culture
- there are opportunities to move up within a company
- the management cares
cons:
-working in tough outdoor conditions
-the job requires you to get "creative " at how you sign people up
- high turnover

pros:
- The underlying nature of the job; reaching out to people and raising funds for a noble cause.
- The art to differentiate yourself from the fundraiser(yourself) whose getting constantly ignored. you realize that its not you they are avoiding, they don't even know you.
- Getting good with ice breakers. These conversation starting skills are absolutely valuable in all forms of employment, and this job definitely gives you a lot of them to practice.
- Its actually a fun Job.
cons:
-Company ideology. To me the whole idea of establishing a connection with the the donors by reaching out to them in public is great, but just not the right thing for a country like Canada. Why would someone want to wait even for a second in the Cold ? and that too when he/she has to donate money at the end.
- The training/evaluation period. Now this one is a bit bizarre. The company asks you to undergo an initial training period, but wait! Theres a a surprise, training is itself the test period.. Many people like me fortunately/unfortunately don't make it through this period as it has some moderately tough targets(Sales/funds) to achieve.
Hence, the extremely high turnover.
- Icing on top. Folks they might not realize this but it actually is a team effort. You wave your hand and its you who gets a person to stop and chat, but just as you are accompanied by a trainer and they continue the conversation, they book the sale. Its you the donor stopped to have a chat and hence the success should be shared not just taken solely by the person whose apparently there to help you be successful.
- Extremely short breaks. This job is not just emotionally demanding due to the NO factor, its also physically demanding. 7 hours of standing in the cold coupled with at least some sort of activity to prove your existence gets very tiring. 
- Extremely low pay. I used "extremely " due to the unproportional work and compensation balance. For the above mentioned reasons at least the pay should be $17, not $14.

review_title: It was rewarding reaching quotas and frustrating in terms of communication and organizing schedules during shifts
pros: Friendly colleagues. Your supervisors assisted in helping you reach your goals and quotas. The work culture was informal and non-hierarchical.
cons: Disorganized and did not receive payments on time. I attended one of my shifts in brampton only to didcover later on that i was not working on that day.

pros:
Outside work, get to interact with public, get to represent awesome causes. 
There's never a dull moment. Great coworkers.
cons: Everyone says the weather, but they're weak. There are no cons except what you choose to believe. Not a job for thin skinned.

review_title: A good place for a student
pros: flexible hours, good skill learning, supportive team, fair pay, great fufulliment if you do well
cons: can be challanging, somewhat difficult to pass the evaluation phase, when you work full time it can be tiring to try and stop people on the street for 5 days in a row

pros: You meet great people and the managers are friendly. It is hourly pay and you can increase pay based on monthly donors signed each week. Managers/ Team leads assess your weekly performance and try to work on improving your pitches
cons: It is not an easy job. Based on your weekly performance you might have to be reassessed to keep the job

pros:
-Work life balance more than any other job I've had
-Managers take the time to do weekly or bi-weekly meetings with individuals to see what they think about the company, the job, or personal life
-Pay is the best for entry level work
cons: -Will eventually get burned out from talking such important world issues with strangers

review_title: Nice people to work with, but really hard to meet job requirement
pros: Your co-workers and manager are nice people. They offer you help and encourage you.
cons: Really hard to meet your job requirement. You need to constantly interrupt people on street or in the mall while they walking or shopping. Might be hard for people who are shy.

pros: Fun work environment and made you feel like your work was making a difference since it was raising money for charity.
cons: The most ridiculously unprofessional place I've ever worked. Absolutely no communication between managers and supervisor. The simply have no respect for you as an employee, because they can't be bothered to contact you or inform you about your standing as a fundraiser. So disappointed.

pros: Great team to work for as they are very down to earth people who will help you become an excellent fundraiser. hourly wage is provided.
cons: Its a job that requires you to get people to sign up. This job is all about numbers. tough work. this is not good for someone who wants to be stable.

pros: Face-to-face interaction with the public, engagement with amazing charitable organizations, transparent and accountable management. I have loved every moment of my employment at PO
cons: Weather is sometimes variable. Work is meant for folks who feel connected to human rights, development and global justice work

review_title: Develop your sales skills and help great causes
pros: Supportive supervisors, great chance to develop your sales and negotiation skills, and recognition for your contribution every few months
cons: Though the company does recruit from within for higher-paying administrative and leadership roles,  there aren't many roles which pay enough to live comfortably off in the long-term.

pros:
- Get to work outside
- Meet many interesting people
- Work on your interpersonal skills
cons:
- Hard to work on days where you aren't in the best mood
- Sucks to work outside on rainy days or in the winter

review_title: Best, most rewarding job I've ever had!
pros:
- Ethically responsible on all levels
- GREAT team culture
- Great appreciation of employees
- Great benefits package (after 6 mos)
- Thorough training and ongoing support
- Hourly wage with rapid increase
cons: Performance-based job (however, I believe commission is unethical for charity fundraising)

pros: Public interaction is interesting and the teams work together when they can.
cons: A company that is like a wolf in sheeps clothing. Be careful of the carefree attitude, when they tell you something is not, it truly is. Without going into much detail it is a simple warning to those who want to venture into this field.  Don't be fooled.

review_title: Hard work and a great culture
pros: There is a great culture here and good team dynamics! The work is hard and at times stressful but it's ethical and they care about their staff.
cons: The weather conditions can be hard and the company should keep that in mind as they scale

review_title: Not the same as it used to be...
pros:
- Lots of Autonomy
- Rapid Advancement Opportunities
- Robust Social Network
- Working Outdoors in the Summer
- Positive Team Culture
cons:
- Tyrannical Upper Management
- Unethical Business Practices
- Misleading Pay Structure
- Inconsistent Management of Staff
- Cultish

review_title: Nice perks, good management, fun job if you like people
pros:
-Free drink and paid for a meeting before every shift
-Get to raise money for some cool charities. Feels good. 
-Fun job with good cooworkers, great if you like to talk to people.
cons: -You have to meet target

pros: People were very nice and sweet. Good salary to start with open communication with managers as well as other teammates. Management seems interested in creating positive work space
cons: Not everyone likes to have to respect performance criterias. Also, not the most organized work place.

pros: The people in the Recruitment Team are very open and respectful as well as professional. Great work environment!
cons: The office could be nicer, newer, cleaner.

job_title: Fundraising Team Leader in Toronto, ON
pros:
Great community, they do genuinely try to help you succeed to the best of your ability
Good support in keeping moral up
Decent pay, FTL's also get TTC fair covered in pay cheque
cons:
Lots of walking
Lots of rejection from potential donors
Its honestly very hard work

review_title: Great place to get awesome sales experience
job_title: Senior Fundraising Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Pros- Great environment for starting fundraising positions as the management and communication is very up much to build and develop your skills.
cons: As you get higher in management, there are areas of internal disputes and unorganized development.

review_title: Young and Energetic team with a startup style work enovironment
job_title: FACE To FACE FUNDRAISER in Toronto, ON
pros:
Team is very supportive.
If you are good at your job you can get promoted fairly quickly
cons: You have to have a certain type of personality to enjoy this work

review_title: In less than five years I worked my way up from a fundraiser to a position in senior management.
job_title: Senior Fundraising Manager in Toronto, ON
pros:
Amazing benefits
Comparative salary
Promotes from within
cons:
Constant pressure to perform
Long hours if your management

pros:
Note: i was working as an IT Specialist in the office. Not as a canvasser.
Great office culture (casual, friendly)
Felt like my superiors actually cared
Got to learn a lot
Enjoyed work!
cons: Lower pay than other companies

review_title: good team work- fair salary- dificult job
job_title: Door to Door Canvasser in Vancouver, BC
pros:
nice team and leader
interact with people
cons:
this is a door to door job, you will work outside all day and get tons of refuse from strangers
each week you should get your goal

pros: They guarantee hourly pay unlike other fundraising companies.
cons: They will kick you out if you fail to meet their fundraising expectations

pros: I lost weight due to all the walking.
cons: They advertise the at a higher rate than they actually pay you. Then, once you say you're committed to the job they tell you the advertised rate is the rate after your probation period. Starting wage was $10 an hour, although advertised as $13 an hour.

pros: friendly colleagues, paid training week, commission on performance
cons: Not a lot of supervision on the first week of work, working conditions can be difficult having to work when it rains, snows and in extreme heat.

review_title: Great Summer Job as a student
pros: flexible hours, being taught and teach about global issues, work for well-known NGOs, very pleasant working atmosphere
cons: Tiring, sometimes have to stay on the field longer, can be psychologically challenging

pros: The overall staff, including Management, are super friendly and supportive.
cons: I don't see any major cons but I would maybe point some lack of organization at the office.

pros: Amazingly patient, kind and generous souls working selflessly for humanity
cons: Everyone is an idealistic egomaniac with delusions of self-importance

pros: Flexible, lots of opportunities for advancement and growth, best job I ever had
cons: I can't think of any, I highly recommend.

pros: Make a quality impact on the world
cons: Stressful, deep subject matter. Sometimes there is a cult like atmosphere within the office.

review_title: It was fine for a little while
pros:
Above minimum wage
Varied work environment
Coworkers are nice enough
cons:
Standing all day
Weather
Quotas
Poor Management
Unprofessional/inappropriate supervisors

pros: Amazing team! The best people to work with.
cons: Nothing really. You should have good people skills though.

pros: Excellent mood amongst the teams, many career opportunities, a company with a purpose, adjustable work schedule
cons: Work under pressure, fast paced job, ever changing job context

review_title: Pretty fun, gotta be on the hustle though
pros: Learn a lot about stopping people and engaging with communication skills
cons: Can be tough, especially when you're not hitting goals

review_title: It`s not for everyone but it is a good experience
pros: You can talk to a wide variety of people
cons: Sales oriented, may not be for everyone

pros:
- Laidback atmosphere
- cool people
- Fun in the office
cons:
- You have to be willing to travel outside of Toronto
- They will cut you like bread in your first few weeks if you do not meet their requirements
- Unclear and very inconsistent rules
-Disorganized

job_title: Professional Street Fundraiser in Toronto, ON
pros: none - too much work for little
cons: They fire like its their day job

pros: Meeting new people and more importantly making a change!
cons: Commute to get to work was a bit stressful

pros:
Great culture
Team-oriented
Company outings are fun
cons:
Lack of leadership
No business sense
Policies change regularly

pros: Hourly wage, work-life balance, non-competitive environment
cons:
Not a suitable job for everyone (not your typical summer job)
Working outdoors can be very draining

pros:
- receive a lot of training 
- supportive coworkers 
- move up quickly
cons:
- low pay 
- office politics

pros: Easy starting job, development opportunities.
cons: Wages are too low, targets too difficult and it's a disorganized management culture.

pros: Incredible work experience. I owe a lot to my time at PO and to Bryan.
cons: Not much I can think of.

pros: Above minimum wage, friendly coworkers, flexible work schedule
cons: Lots of pressure about meeting daily & weekly quotas

pros: Get to talk to lots of people.
cons: Lots of pressure sales and standing

pros: Great staff, good environment, super supportive!
cons: Can be high stress if you don't bode well in performance based jobs

pros: illusion of giving back allows staff to believe they are helping
cons: awful place, awful management, disgusting culture

pros: Supportive environment, mentorship, amazing work environment
cons: It can get draining, need to reach targets- that can get difficult.

pros:
Great People on my team.
Good moral.
cons:
Sometimes pushed fundraising in very low-income areas.
Often fairly disorganized.

pros: Worked with some nice people
cons: I found it very difficult, disheartening, and had no job security.

pros: The opportunity to build strong people skills.
cons: I see no bad it.

pros:
Fun 
Good pay 
Friendly 
Interesting 
Place to learn

Very competitive 
Stressful 
Outside

job_title: Fundraising Team Leader in Toronto, ON
pros: flexible, fun teams and intresting work
cons: lots of turn over and too much responsibility

pros: The team spirit and collaboration is fantastic
cons: The structure is not clear

pros: Love the cause, its great
cons: you need to get donations to get hired fully

pros: Flexible, good pay, motivating staff
cons: There is too much commute

pros: Fun Culture great initial training
cons: no long term job security

pros: It was laid back and some people were nice. Fighting for a good cause.
cons: Poor/disorganised management. Shady co-workers. You have to be emotionally manipulative or you're fired.

pros: It was very laid back and fundraising for a good cause made me feel positive
cons: Had to walk in the super freezing cold to fundraise

pros: improve your sales skills in a short period time.
cons: majority of people don't last through training week, fundraising on the street is hard work.

pros: Chill and nice coworkers
cons: Making money for them but portending it is for the good when it is only for money

pros: Nice co workers is really the only pro
cons: Horrible management, the job itself is soul sucking

pros:
-coworkers are cool
-pay is okay
cons:

- they dont care about you unless you hit your goals

pros: None I cant think of any
